shared_text:
Sonoran Science Academy Tucson
September 2, 2019 at 4:57 PM ·

SSA-Tucson alumnus strikes gold!

Congratulations to Nabahi Ramos Hickman, our latest CMLP (College Mentorship Leadership Program) Gold Medal recipient.
The CMLP gold medal is the highest honor that Congress awards to youth, recognizing completion of over 400 hours of volunteer service, 200 hours in both personal development and physical fitness, as well as an organized trip of at least 5 consecutive days of expedition and exploration.
Nabahi graduated with honors from SSA Tucson last May and will be attending the University of Hawaii - Manoa this Fall. At a distance of 2,963 miles from Tucson, it may rank as the farthest distance an SSA student has traveled thus far to attend a University! Please join us in congratulating Nabahi on his success in the comments below!

post_text: Amazing work at SSA DM, and a fantastic opportunity for our students to showcase their engineering skills!
shared_text:
SSA Davis-Monthan
May 4, 2019 at 3:28 PM ·

Congrats to our "Racing the Sun" team for their great performance! Last Saturday, the Sonoran Science Academy DM's Solar Race Kart team, "I Can't Read This", participated in their first solar kart race at Tech Parks Arizona’s Racing the Sun competition.
In its 8th year, this unique competition challenges high school students to design, build, and test a solar go-kart. It was held at the Musselman Honda Circuit and saw more than 100 students from Phoenix, Tucson, and southern Arizona race their solar-powered karts and show off their engineering and science skills.
In its first ever competition, Team “I Can’t Read This” garnered the Best Verbal Presentation Award and the Innovation Award. The team also placed 2nd in the Endurance category and the Speed category. What an amazing rookie year achievement!
For more information and to see lots of great photos of the event, visit: https://techparks.arizona.edu/high-school-solar-powered-go-kart-race-success

Students in Ms. Hanson's AP Government class used mock primary debates to learn more about the political process.
For the past several weeks, student groups have been taking the roles of party leaders, campaign managers and candidates for the Democrat, Republican, and TEA party. Students have had to develop campaign strategies to understand the demographics of the constituents and determine how to win the required 270 electoral votes, a media plan to get out their message and address a political scandal, party platforms, candidate posters, stump speeches and ultimately preparing for the debates.
"I have been amazed at how this project has given students a buy-in to really learn the election process, and I have been impressed by their effort and the quality of their work," said Ms. Hanson.

At SSA Broadway, Mr. Abdullah's 7th grade class wanted to answer the question: how do adaptations and environmental changes affect traits? To prepare, students read Darwin's observations of birds and natural selection. Then, they decided to recreate his experiments in the classroom.
Students were assigned different "beaks," represented by different shaped-tools, like tongs, toothpicks, spoons, or a pair of tweezers. Then, students were given a plate full of different shaped foods, like marshmallows, rice, sunflowers, and marbles. Using their beaks, students had to collect s much food as they could in 10 seconds.
They deduced that selection pressure from the environment (types of food available) determined which traits (beak shape) will allow an organism to survive. And they had a lot of fun doing it! :)
